utterances: There has been - really since the very early days of the involvement in Iraq - a great deal of interest in information.
What's going on?
How are things going?
What's working?
What isn't?

I think the American public understands that Iraq is better off with Saddam removed from power, but frustrated that progress there hasn't been better; that the Iraqi people don't seem to be responding as we might expect to the opportunity to select their own government, to take more responsibility for their own security.
So a lot of frustration and a lot of questions about what tactics and approaches might make the most sense to ensure success there - stability - and allow our troops to come home.

Well, given that we're in the midst of a lot of talk about what makes the most sense, are there any recommendations on Iraq from the Iraq Study Group, from the administration, Democrats, that you think are unacceptable?
I think just removing troops without setting a goal for the Iraq people - for governing structure, revision of oil law, reconciliation process -I think that would be a mistake.

I think refusing to make any changes in tactics or approaches is unacceptable, given that we can look and see what's happening in Iraq and recognize that we aren't being as successful as we'd like to be.
And, we can look back and say, we made some bad choices.
There were mistakes that have been made.
I think the recommendations made in the Iraq Study Group report, by and large, hit the mark.
I certainly agree with the significant majority of them.

There may be other ideas and important input that's going to come from commanders in the field, but I think the president has a good platform now to act, to act with clarity, and people understand that making new decisions - changing the approach - is to be expected of any commander in chief during this kind of an effort.
President Bush has said now that he'll be waiting until January to announce any new strategy on Iraq.
As increasingly chaotic and bloody as Iraq is day by day, is that too late?

It's not too late, but my preference would have been for the administration, along with the new secretary of defense, to put forward a set of recommendations and policy decisions based on the Study Group report and their own internal review, earlier.
But we do have a new secretary of defense.

I think, in part, the delay is an accommodation to Robert Gates and his desire to have a little bit more time, so that when the administration and the Defense Department does act, they stand the best chance of getting it right.
Well, given the levels of support for the Iraq war among the American people, and how that support is going down, politically speaking, does the president have this much time to act?
I think it would be a mistake for the president, or the Democratic leadership in Congress for that matter, to be focused on the political implications of a particular decision.
Though the political decisions in this case involve the support of the American people for whatever is decided.
Look, the support of the American people is crucial, but I think if we make good decisions about the path forward in Iraq, the American people will be supportive.
There is a lot of truth to this sentiment - and it may be clich√© - that this is a little bit too important to be driven strictly by poll numbers.
So, sooner is always better than later, but getting it right is most important of all.
Senator, thank you very much for speaking with us.
It's a real pleasure to be with you.
Republican Senator John Sununu is a member of the Foreign Relations Committee.
This is All Things Considered from NPR News.
I'm Robert Siegel.
And I'm Michele Norris.
In the midst of the recession, there is a mega-deal to report today.
The largest drug maker in the world, Pfizer, has agreed to buy a smaller rival, Wyeth.
The price tag - $68 billion in cash and stock.
There aren't many companies lining up that kind of money these days.
The patent on Pfizer's cholesterol drug, Lipitor, runs out in two-and-a-half years, and that may be one reason Pfizer is so eager to gobble up Wyeth.
NPR's Yuki Noguchi reports.
This time, the wire bumps up against the inside wall of the heart and curls over.
No, no, no, no, no.
Tworetzky remembers how tense it was.
It's like trying to find a golf ball in a snowstorm.
They make another try.
OK, hold on right there.
And finally, they hit the target.
I think that's across the valve.
Yeah.
I think it's across.
Yeah.
Me, too.
They inflate the balloon.
All right, do it again.
Do it again.
Meanwhile, the clock is ticking.
Dr. Tworetzky says time was critical.
We really have to get this done - either within seconds or at most, several minutes.
Several minutes from when?
From when the needle is first placed inside the heart.
Otherwise, there's a danger the fetus's heart will slow down.
If the heart slows down or even stops, there's a chance that we may lose the fetus.
And in fact, the tiny heart does slow down.
Then another bad sign: fluid around the heart.
That can compress the heart.
Which can also be fatal.
So the lead doctor makes the call.
He says, bring everything out of the body; it's time to stop the operation.
Just everything out of the body.
They quickly pull out the guide wire, the balloon and the long needle.
At this point, nobody can be sure if the operation was a success.
As the pregnancy continued, ultrasound scans showed things were looking good.
And when Kim Wells had her baby girl four months later, the newborn's heart had developed normally.
My name is Hannah Wells, and I'm 4 years old.
She runs circles around our oldest daughter, who's completely healthy.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
Yeah, she's a ball of energy.
Hannah did need two heart operations to do a little bit more work on that valve, and she'll probably need some more down the road.
But her father, John Wells, says that's nothing.
She has four chambers of her heart that are functioning.
Yes.
So that is the success story of the fetal intervention.
Richard Knox, NPR News, Boston.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
